intro: Tibouchina sulcata, commonly known as the Brazilian flame bush, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 6 meters tall, featuring broad, ovate leaves with a leathery texture. The plant produces clusters of showy, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to red, attracting pollinators like hummingbirds and bees. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soil and full sun. Tibouchina sulcata is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in coastal environments.
